facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1576 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1576 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and ordered dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 26, 1965 of Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 174 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and ordered dated October 26. 1965 of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 174 of 1964.

facts.text: Appellant company incorporated in August 1942 with registered office in Jullundur dealing in sale and purchase of land.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of August, 1942 the appellant companypany  hereinafter called the Company  was incorporated -with its registered office in the city of Jullundur dealing in sale and purchase of land as its substantial business.

facts.text: Company purchased 646 karnals, 9 marlas of land from Harjit Singh by sale deed on November 24, 1944 for Rs. 32,326/- located in village Monanpura, District Sheikupura, West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: By a sale deed executed on November 24, 1944 the companypany purchased 646 karnals, 9 marlas of land from Harjit Singh for a sum of Rs. 32,326/-. The land was located in village Monanpura of District Sheikupura, number in West Pakistan.

facts.text: Out of consideration Rs. 9,000/- left with company for payment to previous mortgagees, balance paid to Harjit Singh before Sub-Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the companysideration for the sale, a sum of Rs. 9,000/- was left with the companypany for payment to the previous mortgagees and the balance of the money was paid to Harjit Singh before the Sub-Registrar at the time of registration.

facts.text: Company allotted 27 standard acres and 11 1/2 units of land in village Bohani, Tehsil Phagwara, District Kapurthala in 1950 in lieu of land abandoned in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the registered sale deed the companypany was allotted 27 standard acres and 11 1/2 units of land village Bohani, Tehsil Phagwara District Kapurthala in the year 1950 in lieu of the land abandoned in Pakistan.

facts.text: Sanad number K2/4/8 dated March 9, 1950 issued in favour of company.

anchor.surface_text: A sanad number K2/4/8 dated March 9, 1950 was issued in favour of the companypany.

facts.text: Consolidation of holdings in village Bohani resulted in area allotted to company becoming 23 kanals and 5 marlas.

anchor.surface_text: There was companysolidation of holdings in village Bohani and as a result of companysolidation the area allotted to the companypany came to 23 kanals and 5 marlas.

facts.text: Company sold 9-1/2 kanals to Mohan Singh of village Bohani for Rs. 1900 by registered sale deed dated May 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this the companypany sold 9-1/2 kanals to Mohan Singh, a Jar of village Bohani for Rs. 1900.00 by registered sale deed dated May 22, 1956.

facts.text: Company sold another portion of 220 kanals and 15 marlas on September 12, 1958 for Rs. 10,012/- to Mehnga Singh and his sons.

anchor.surface_text: Another portion of 220 kanals and 15 marlas was sold on September 12, 1958 for Rs. 10,012/- to one Mehnga Singh and his sons.

facts.text: Additional area of 24 kanals allotted to company in village Bohani to make up deficiency from consolidation.

anchor.surface_text: It was later discovered that the companypany had been allotted less area of land than it was entitled to as a result of companysolidation operations and so. an additional area of 24 kanals was allotted to the companypany in village Bohani to make up the deficiency.

facts.text: Managing Officer, respondent number 3, made report Annexure C on August 30, 1960 to Chief Settlement Commissioner, respondent number 2, recommending cancellation of allotment and grant of permanent rights to company.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1960 the Managing Officer, respondent number 3, made a report, Annexure C, to the Chief Settlement Commissioner, Respondent number 2 recommending cancellation of the allotment of land to the companypany and companysequently the grant of permanent rights to it.

facts.text: Company was heard by Chief Settlement Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was heard by the Chief Settlement Commissioner and thereafter the Chief Settlement Commissioner rejected the registered sale deed and balance sheets and relying on the jamabandi, annexure X,

facts.text: Chief Settlement Commissioner rejected registered sale deed and balance sheets, relied on jamabandi annexure X, concluded company did not own or occupy land in Pakistan at partition.

anchor.surface_text: came to the companyclusion that at the time of partition the companypany did number own any, land in Pakistan number was it in occupation of any such land.

facts.text: Chief Settlement Commissioner by order dated February 27, 1961 set aside permanent rights of 27 standard acres 11 1/2 units and cancelled quasi-permanent allotment to company.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated February 27, 1961 respondent number 2 set aside the permanent rights acquired by the companypany to the extent of 27 standard acres, 111/2 units and also cancelled the quasi-permanent allotment of the ,land made in the name of the companypany.

facts.text: Revision petition filed by company to Central Government, respondent number 1, on March 29, 1961, dismissed on May 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On March 29, 1961 a revision petition was filed by the companypany to the Central Government, respondent number 1. But the revision petition was dismissed on May 10, 1961.

facts.text: Writ petition filed by company under Art. 226 on June 8, 1961 to quash CSC order dated February 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On June 8, 1961 the companypany filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for grant of a writ to quash the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner dated February 27, 1961.

facts.text: Writ petition allowed by Shamshat Bahadur, J. on November 28, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was allowed by Shamshat Bahadur, J. But the respondent took the matter in appeal under el. 10 of Letters Patent to a Division Bench which reversed the judgment of the learned single Judge

facts.text: Division Bench reversed single judge and dismissed writ petition by judgment dated October 26, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: and ordered the writ petition to be dismissed. Section 24 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954  44 of 1954   hereinafter called the Act  states The Chief Settlement Commissioner may at any time call for the record o any proceeding under this Act

facts.text: On behalf of company contended that jamabandi annexure II was not of 1946-47 but consisted of notes dated May 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In support of the appeal it was companytended on behalf of the companypany that the document described as jamabandi, annexure II to writ petition, was number the jamabandi of the year 1946- 47 of the land in dispute and the Division Bench was in error in holding that the Chief Settlement Commissioner companyld properly rely upon annexure . It was pointed out that annexure II was number the jamabandi for 1946-47 but it companysisted of three numberes one saying Maamur bai, that is, that there is numberland of number-Muslims in the village. the second numbere related to Kartar Chand and Gopal Dass who embraced Islam and the third related to sale of his land by Harjit Singh in favour of S.A. Latif. All these numberes are dated May 3, 1951.

facts.text: Chief Settlement Commissioner recorded finding that company had not proved title to land in village Monanpura and allotment was undeserved.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Chief Settlement Commissioner had recorded a finding that the companypany had number proved its title to any land in village Momonpura and the allotment was undeserved.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no finding by CSC that company obtained allotment by fraud, false representation or concealment of material fact under s.24(2).

anchor.surface_text: But this is number tantamount to a finding that the allotment had been obtained by a false representation or fraud or companycealment of material facts. Such a finding is a companydition precedent for taking action under s. 24 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, reversed Division Bench judgment dated October 26, 1965, restored judgment of Shamshat Bahadur J. dated November 28, 1963 quashing CSC order.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Division Bench dated October 26, 1965 in Letters Patent Appeal should be reversed and the judgment of Shamshat Bahadur, J., dated November 28, 1963 quashing the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner dated February 27, 1961 should be restored.

facts.text: Appeal allowed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts.

facts.text: Section 24 of Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 empowers Chief Settlement Commissioner to review orders for fraud etc.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act, 1954  44 of 1954   hereinafter called the Act  states The Chief Settlement Commissioner may at any time call for the record o any proceeding under this Act in which a Settlement Officer, an Assistant Settlement Officer, an Assistant Settlement Commissioner, an Additional Settlement Commissioner, a Settlement Commissioner, a managing officer or a managing companyporation has passed an order for the purpose of satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of any such order and may pass such order in relation thereto as he thinks fit. Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power under sub-section  1  , if the Chief Settlement Commissioner is satisfied that any order for payment of companypensation to a displaced person or any lease or allotment granted to such a person has been obtained by him by means of fraud, false representation or companycealment of any material fact, then, numberwithstanding anything companytained in this Act, the Chief Settlement Commissioner may pass an order directing that numbercompensation shall be paid to such a person or reducing the amount of companypensation to be paid to him, or as the case may be, canceling the lease or allotment granted to him and if it is found that a displaced person has been paid companypensation which is number payable to him, or which is in excess of the amount payable to him, Such amount or excess, as the case may be, may on a certificate issued by the Chief Settlement Commissioner be recovered in the same manner as an arrear of land revenue.
the companypany filed a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for grant of a writ to quash the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner

Section 24 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 44 of 1954 hereinafter called the Act states The Chief Settlement Commissioner may at any time call for the record o any proceeding under this Act

issues.text: Whether the document described as jamabandi annexure II was the jamabandi of the year 1946-47 of the land in dispute and whether the Chief Settlement Commissioner could properly rely upon it

anchor.surface_text: In support of the appeal it was contended on behalf of the companypany that the document described as jamabandi, annexure II to writ petition, was number the jamabandi of the year 1946- 47 of the land in dispute and the Division Bench was in error in holding that the Chief Settlement Commissioner companyld properly rely upon annexure . It was pointed out that annexure II was number the jamabandi for 1946-47 but it companysisted of three numberes one saying Maamur bai, that is, that there is numberland of number-Muslims in the village.

issues.text: Whether there is a finding of the Chief Settlement Commissioner that the Company had obtained allotment of the land by means of fraud, false representation or concealment of any material fact within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Act, which is a mandatory condition precedent for cancellation of the allotment

anchor.surface_text: the Company had obtained allotment of the land by means of fraud, false representation or concealment of any material fact within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Act. It is true that the Chief Settlement Commissioner had recorded a finding that the companypany had number proved its title to any land in village Momonpura and the allotment was undeserved. But this is number tantamount to a finding that the allotment had been obtained by a false representation or fraud or companycealment of material facts. Such a finding is a companydition precedent

arguments.court_reasoning: Chief Settlement Commissioner lacked jurisdiction under s.24(2) without mandatory finding of fraud etc.

arguments.claim: Finding that allotment obtained by fraud, false representation or concealment of material fact under s.24(2) is mandatory condition precedent for cancellation; no such finding exists so no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to examine this document in detail for we are of opinion that the appeal must be allowed and the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner must be quashed on the ground that there is no finding of the Chief Settlement Commissioner that the Company had obtained allotment

holdings.text: there is no finding of the Chief Settlement Commissioner that the Company had obtained allotment of the land by means of fraud, false representation or concealment of any material fact within the meaning of s. 24(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to examine this document in detail for we are of opinion that the appeal must be allowed and the order of the Chief Settlement Commissioner must be quashed on the ground that there is numberfinding of the Chief Settlement Commissioner that the Company had obtained allotment of the land by means of fraud, false representation or companycealment of any material fact within the meaning of s. 24 2  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines record and finds no explicit determination by CSC of fraud, false representation, or concealment as required by statute

holdings.text: the Chief Settlement Commissioner had recorded a finding that the company had not proved its title to any land in village Momonpura and the allotment was undeserved. But this is not tantamount to a finding that the allotment had been obtained by a false representation or fraud or concealment of material facts

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Chief Settlement Commissioner had recorded a finding that the companypany had number proved its title to any land in village Momonpura and the allotment was undeserved. But this is number tantamount to a finding that the allotment had been obtained by a false representation or fraud or companycealment of material facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court distinguishes between failure to prove title/undeserved allotment and the specific vitiating elements of fraud/false representation/concealment statutorily required

holdings.text: Such a finding is a condition precedent for taking action under s. 24(2) of the Act. The condition imposed by the section is mandatory and in the absence of any such finding the Chief Settlement Commissioner had no jurisdiction to cancel the allotment made to the company under s. 24(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Such a finding is a companydition precedent for taking action under s. 24 2  of the Act. The companydition imposed by the section is mandatory and in the absence of any such finding the Chief Settlement Commissioner had ,no jurisdiction to cancel the allotment made to the companypany under s. 24 2  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language of s.24(2) interpreted to require explicit satisfaction and finding of fraud etc. as mandatory precondition to exercise cancellation power, depriving jurisdiction otherwise

The appeal is accordingly allowed with companysits.
